metadata.title: Photoelectrochemical regeneration of all vanadium redox species for construction of a solar rechargeable flow cell

S2095-4956(17)30177-8 10.1016/j.jechem.2017.04.005 Science Press Fig. 1 Schematic diagram of the solar rechargeable flow cell. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) Current-potential curves of the TiO2 photoelectrode under various conditions, (b) IPCE of the PEC cells under an applied potential of 0.3V vs. SCE in different electrolytes. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) Photocharge curve of the SRFC at a bias of 0.2V under 100mW/cm2 irradiation. Both of the initial anolyte and catholyte are 0.05M VOSO4 + 0.1M H2SO4 solutions. (b) The UV–vis absorption spectra of electrolytes before and after photocharge. (c) Discharge curve of the SRFC under dark condition at a discharge current of 0.1mA. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) I–t curve of the TiO2 photoelectrode in blank H2SO4 solution at a bias of 0.7V under 100mW/cm2 irradiation; (b) Discharge curve of the capacitor in blank H2SO4 solution. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Capacities versus cycle number of SRFC photocharged under 0.1V bias. Fig 5 Table 1 Electrochemical performance of the SRFC under various biases. Table 1 U bias C photocharge C discharge η coulombic E discharge ΔE η savings (V) (mAh/L) (mAh/L) (%) (mWh/L) (mWh/L) (%) 0.1 75.0 61.3 81.8 23.0 15.5 67.4 0.2 171.3 109.2 63.7 44.2 9.9 22.4 0.3 231.6 132.1 57.0 55.0 — — Notes: The SRFC is photocharged for 1h at different biases under 100mW/cm2 irradiation. The galvanostatically discharge of the SRFC is performed at a current of 0.1mA under dark condition. Solutions of 0.05M VOSO4 + 0.1M H2SO4 are used as the initial anolyte and catholyte, respectively. Photoelectrochemical regeneration of all vanadium redox species for construction of a solar rechargeable flow cell Shichao Liao a b Jingying Shi a Chunmei Ding a Mingyao Liu a Fengqiang Xiong a Nan Wang a Jian Chen a * Can Li a * a State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences; Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, iCHEM, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences; Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, iCHEM Liaoning Dalian 116023 China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Energy storage is pivotal for the continuous utilization of solar energy suffering from the intermittency issue. Herein, we demonstrate a solar rechargeable flow cell (SRFC) based on photoelectrochemical regeneration of vanadium redox species for in-situ solar energy harvest and storage. In this device, TiO2 and MWCNT/acetylene black (MWCNT/AB) composite are served as the photoanode and the counter electrode, respectively, with all vanadium redox couples, VO2 +/VO2+ and VO2+/V3+, as solar energy storage media. Benefitting from solar energy, the cell can be photocharged under a bias as low as 0.1V, which is much lower than the discharge voltage of ∼0.5V. Photocharged under the optimized condition, the cell delivers a discharge energy of 23.0mWh/L with 67.4% input electric energy savings. This prototype work may inspire the rational design for cost-effective solar energy storage devices. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Utilizing solar energy, the solar rechargeable flow cell based on photoelectrochemical regeneration of vanadium redox species can be photocharged under a bias as low as 0.1 V with 67.4% input electric energy savings. Keywords Photoelectrocatalysis Vanadium species Photocharge Solar energy storage 1 Introduction Due to the intermittent nature of sunlight, solar energy utilization via photovoltaic devices meets with insurmountable limitations in practical applications [1–5]. Converting solar-electricity into chemical energy stored in external electrochemical energy storage devices could address the above issue [6–9]. However, this approach suffers from the problems such as the complicated structure and substantial energy loss during the multistep energy conversion and storage process [10]. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop a device with simplified processes for the direct capture and storage of solar energy. Photoelectrochemical (PEC) synthesis of useful chemicals presents an alternative approach to storing solar energy in the form of chemical energy. If the reversible redox couples are applied as active species in the PEC conversion reactions, the products may be utilized on demand in a rechargeable battery. In this regard, preliminary efforts have been devoted to combining photoelectrolysis cells with energy storage devices. For instance, early researchers introduced a dye sensitized solar cell (DSSC) into an energy storage device for simultaneous solar energy harvest and storage [11–13]. However, the devices encounter challenges such as large internal resistance of brittle ceramic separators with low conductivity and high cost of noble metal platinum. Up to now, intensive efforts have been directed for improving the performance of the integrated devices [14–16]. Recently, our group reported an efficient solar rechargeable flow cell (SRFC) based on a dual-silicon PEC cell and a water-soluble quinone/bromine redox flow battery (RFB), achieving an overall solar energy conversion efficiency of 3.2% for the complete photocharge/discharge cycle [14]. Thus, PEC regeneration of electroactive species to directly charge all-aqueous SRFCs represents an ideal approach for in-situ solar energy conversion and storage. Vanadium redox flow battery (VRB) has been considered as a promising candidate for large-scale energy storage because of its advantages like the long cycle life, the decoupling of power and energy, and the facility of electrolyte regeneration when the cross contamination occurs [17]. The standard redox potential of the couple VO2 +/VO2+ is 1.000V vs. RHE, which is about 0.23V more negative compared to that of the water oxidation reaction (2H2O→4H++O2 +e― 1.229V vs. RHE) and is helpful for reducing the influence of oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Furthermore, it is indicated that PEC oxidation of VO2+ has been realized on the surface of common semiconductors [18–20]. In view of these matters, the vanadium redox couples could be potential electroactive species for a SRFC. Herein, we report a SRFC system based on all vanadium redox couples, in which TiO2 and MWCNT/acetylene black (MWCNT/AB) composite with a large hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) overpotential are served as the photoelectrode and the counter electrode, respectively. The redox couples VO2 +/VO2+ and VO2+/V3+ (0.334V vs. RHE), thermodynamically more favorable than water splitting reactions, are employed as the active species in anolyte and catholyte, respectively. The anode and cathode compartments are separated by a Nafion 117 membrane to conduct the protons and prevent the contamination of the redox couples. Upon illumination, the cell can be photocharged under an ultralow bias of 0.1V, which is much lower than discharge voltage of ∼0.5V. Photocharged under the optimized condition, the cell delivers a discharge energy of 23.0mWh/L, 67.4% of which is contributed by solar energy. The feasibility of this new configuration of the SRFC paves the way for in-situ solar energy conversion and storage. 2 Experimental 2.1 Fabrication of photoelectrodes and counter electrodes The TiO2 photoelectrodes were prepared by employing a hydrothermal method [21]. In a typical synthesis, 15mL concentrated HCl and 15mL deionized water were mixed and stirred for 5min, and then 0.4mL titanium butoxide was dropped into the mixture under magnetic stirring. After stirring for another 10min, the solution and a clean FTO glass substrate were transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated at 180°C for 3h. After the heating period, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature under a slow stream of tap water. The substrate was thoroughly rinsed with deionized water, dried in air, and finally treated in air at 450°C for 1h. In order to define the active area of photoelectrode (∼3cm2), the substrate edges and the metal contact region were sealed with nonconductive epoxy resin. Counter electrodes were prepared as follows. The pristine MWCNT was treated by refluxing in mixed acid (H2SO4:HNO3 = 3:1 in volume) at 70°C for 8h [22,23]. Afterward, the treated sample was filtered, washed extensively with deionized water to pH 7, and dried at 60°C. The modified MWCNT was mixed with acetylene black and polyvinylidene difluoride (8:1:1 in weight) in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone. Finally, the mixture was coated onto a graphite plate and dried at 60°C before use. The working area of counter electrodes (MWCNT/AB) was ∼3cm2. 2.2 Physical and PEC characterization The morphology of the TiO2 was examined using a scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Quanta 200FEG). The photoresponse measurement of the photoelectrode was performed using a three-electrode configuration with the TiO2, saturated calomel electrode (SCE), and MWCNT/AB as working, reference and counter electrode, respectively. The electrolyte used was 0.05M VOSO4 + 0.1M H2SO4 solution in all cases unless otherwise specified. Linear sweep voltammetry was recorded by a CHI 760D electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua Instruments, China) with a scanning rate of 50mV/s. To simulate solar irradiation, the light source was a Xe lamp (300W, PLS-SXE 300C) and the intensity was 100mW/cm2. For all PEC measurements reported herein, photoelectrode was illuminated from the backside side and ultrahigh purity Ar was bubbled to remove the dissolved oxygen from the solution. The MS plot was measured on a PARSTAT 2273 electrochemical workstation (Princeton Applied 20 Research) in 0.05M VOSO4 + 0.1M H2SO4 electrolyte (pH 0.71). 2.3 Solar rechargeable flow cell tests The photocharge process of the SRFC was carried out in a homemade two-electrode photo-reactor. The TiO2 photoelectrode and MWCNT/AB composite were employed as working electrode and counter electrode, respectively. Both of the initial anolyte and catholyte were 3.8mL 0.05M VOSO4 + 0.1M H2SO4 solutions, which were continuously bubbled with ultrahigh purity Ar during the tests. I–t tests under different biases were measured by a CHI 760D electrochemical workstation under 100mW/cm2 irradiation with a 300W xenon lamp. All measurements reported herein were run with the backside illumination. After irradiation, the concentrations of VO2+ in both anolyte and catholyte were analyzed with UV–visible (UV–vis) spectrophotometer. The cell was galvanostatically discharged at a current of 0.1mA on Neware battery testing system, while two pieces of graphite plate with MWCNT/AB were used as positive and negative electrodes, respectively. The lower limit of discharge voltage was 0.01V. By comparison, control experiments were conducted as follows. PEC water splitting reactions were also measured with the backside illumination, replacing the 0.05M VOSO4 + 0.1M H2SO4 electrolytes with blank H2SO4 solutions. Afterward, the discharge of the cell was evaluated in the same way. Electrolysis experiments were carried out without illumination, replacing the photoelectrode with the counter electrode. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 illustrates the configuration and working principle of the SRFC that employs VO2 +/VO2+ and VO2+/V3+ as the electroactive species. The anode compartment is fitted with TiO2 (nanorod arrays in morphology, Fig. S1) as photoanode (PE) during photocharge and MWCNT/AB as positive electrode (CE1) during discharge. The cathode compartment contains MWCNT/AB (CE2) working as counter electrode during photocharge and negative electrode during discharge. During photocharge process, the PE and CE2 are connected, while the CE1 is open-circuit. Once illuminated, PE will absorb the photons of hv > E g. Subsequently, electrons will jump from the valance band to the conduction band. Driven by the electric field existing in the space charge region, the minority carriers (h+) sweep toward the surface to participate in the oxidation reaction of VO2+; while the majority carriers (e−) migrate to the counter electrode via the external circuit to take part in the reduction reaction of VO2+. In this regard, the photogenerated electrons and holes are separately stored in the redox couples. During the discharge process, the CE1 and CE2 are short-circuited and the discharge reactions of the battery take place at the surface of counter electrodes. Cell reactions involved in the above-described process could be written as follows: (1) V O 2 + + H 2 O − − − − − − − − − ⟶ ⟵ − − − − − − − − − discharge photocharge 2 H + + VO 2 + + e − E θ = 1.000 V vs . RHE (2) V O 2 + + 2 H + + e − − − − − − − − − − ⟶ ⟵ − − − − − − − − − discharge photocharge V 3 + + H 2 O E θ = 0.337 V vs . RHE According to the working principle, PEC oxidation of VO2+ is the primary reaction during photocharge of the SRFC. Therefore, the PEC oxidation of VO2+ on TiO2 photoelectrode is firstly performed in a three-electrode configuration with the TiO2 nanowire, SCE, and MWCNT/AB as working, reference and counter electrode, respectively. Fig. 2 (a) shows that the photoelectrode produces insignificant currents both in H2SO4 solutions with and without VOSO4 in the dark. Under illumination, a noticeable photocurrent in blank H2SO4 solution is not observed until the potential approaches to 0.13V vs. SCE. After the addition of 0.05M VOSO4 solution into the electrolyte, the photocurrent improves and the onset potential of photocurrent is negatively shifted by about 0.12V, implying the PEC oxidation of VO2+ species. Photogenerated holes transferred to the semiconductor surface can quickly oxidize VO2+ species, since the standard redox potential of VO2+/VO2+ (1.000V vs. RHE) is more negative than that of H2O/O2 (1.229V vs. RHE). For this reason, recombinations of photogenerated charge carriers at the surface of the semiconductor will be inhibited, resulting in the enhanced photoresponse [18]. Fig. 2(b) demonstrates the IPCE of the PEC cells in different electrolytes. As expected, a higher incident photon-to-current efficiency (IPCE) of 50% at 380nm is achieved in the solution with 0.05M VOSO4 compared to that (42%) in blank H2SO4 electrolyte, manifesting the efficient oxidation of VO2+ species. By comparison, the results of control experiments indicate that there is no change in the concentration of VO2+ after suffering illumination for 1h in the absence of PE (Fig. S2) or when the PE is under open-circuit condition (Fig. S3). And the dark current of PE is in the scale of uA in the potential range of 0V–1V vs. SCE (Fig. S4). All these results confirm that the PEC oxidation of VO2+ species can be attributed to a synergistic effect of light irradiation and applied potential. After achievement of the efficient PEC oxidation of VO2+, we then consider to constructing the proposed SRFC. Charge processes of the cell are conducted under dark and illumination, respectively. The traditional electrochemical charge of the cell is conducted with two counter electrodes. The electrochemical charge of the cell requires a bias of 0.7V (Fig. S5), which is close to the equilibrium potential difference between two vanadium couples (0.666V). While in our SRFC, as shown in Fig. 3 (a), the required external bias can be reduced to 0.2V under solar illumination. The reduced bias is benefitted from the solar energy, indicating the input electric energy savings. During illumination, the photocurrent in Fig. 3(a) decreases from 0.7mA to 0.6mA. The gradual decay of the photocurrent is due to the light absorption of produced VO2 + together with the shifts of the Nernst redox potential of the redox couples, which is caused by concentration change of vanadium species and H+ in the electrolytes as expressed in Eq. (3): (3) U = ( E A θ − E C θ ) − R T F ln a V O 2 + ( anolyte ) a V O 2 + ( catholyte ) a H + ( catholyte ) a VO 2 + a V 3 + ( anolyte ) a H + ( anolyte ) where U is the cell voltage, Eθ represents the standard redox potential at the absolute temperature T, R stands for the gas constant (8.314J/(Kmol), F denotes the Faraday constant, and a is the activity of the relevant species. The cell voltage is expected to increase with time due to the reduction of VO2+ concentration both in anolyte and catholyte. In this case, a larger driving force is required to drive the redox reactions. To detect the concentration change of VO2+, the electrolytes after photocharge are analyzed with UV–visible spectrophotometer, a general method for the detection of vanadium species in VRB [24–26], and the results are illustrated in Fig. 3(b). It is seen that the characteristic absorption peak at 765.5nm assigned to the VO2+ reactant decreases both in anolyte and catholyte. The characteristic absorption peaks at 400nm and 600nm attributed to the V3+ product appear in the catholyte [25]. The absorption of the anolyte in UV region increases remarkably after photocharge, confirming the production of VO2 +. The production of VO2 + and V3+ manifests that the incident solar energy and input electric energy have been stored as chemical energy, which is ready for discharging under dark condition. The typical galvanostatic discharge curve of the SRFC is given in Fig. 3(c). At the beginning of discharge, the cell voltage drops sharply, which is reasonably ascribed to the internal ohmic resistance of the cell [27]. Then, the cell voltage decreases smoothly in the region of 0.40–0.54V. The slow decline in cell voltage is predominantly resulted from the gradual conversions of the vanadium species, which can also be explained according to Eq. (3). At the end of discharge, the dramatically decrease in voltage is primarily attributed to the concentration polarization. After discharge, the SRFC delivers a discharge capacity of 109.2mAh/L. To estimate the effects of capacitor on the performance of SRFC, the controlled experiment is performed by replacing the electrolyte of 0.05M VOSO4 + 0.1M H2SO4 with the blank H2SO4 electrolyte. As there is not any vanadium species in the blank solution, water splitting reactions occur during PEC test. Fig. 4 (a) shows that a high bias of 0.7V is required to maintain the photocurrent at 0.55mA. The external bias is higher than that (0.2V) applied in SRFC while the photocurrent is smaller compared to that (0.7–0.6mA) in Fig. 3(a). The desirable photocharge of the SRFC benefits from PEC reactions of VO2+ species. The discharge capacity ascribed to the capacitor is only 3.5mAh/L, as shown in Fig. 4(b), which is much smaller than that (109.2mAh/L) of SRFC in Fig. 3(c). This indicates that the influence of the capacitor on the performance of SRFC can be neglected and the discharge capacity of the SRFC comes from the proposed discharge reactions. In order to get further understanding of the role of external bias and photon energy during photocharge, the photocharge of SRFC is conducted under various biases. The results are presented in Table 1 . The U fb of PE is above the E(VO2+/V3+) (Fig. S6), which meets the thermodynamic requirement for the conversion from VO2+ to V3+. However, the cell could not be photocharged without any bias due to the parasitic energy losses resulted from the overpotential for the oxidation and reduction of VO2+. To overcome the additional energy losses and the overpotential during photocharge, a bias of 0.1V should be applied and the SRFC delivers a charge capacity of 75.0mAh/L. As the bias increases to 0.2V, the charge capacity of the SRFC increases obviously by a factor up to 2.3, implying that the external bias facilitates charge separation and enhances forward current. A further improved bias to 0.3V does not improve the charge capacity significantly, which is consistent with the I–E curve in Fig. 2(a). The overall coulombic efficiency η coulombic in the whole photocharge and discharge process could be calculated by the following equation: (4) η coulombic = C discharge / C photocharge × 100 % = C discharge / ( ∫ i ( t ) d t ) × 100 % where C discharge is the discharge capacity, C photocharge stands for the photocharge capacity, i(t) represents the photocurrent during photocharge. From Table 1, the coulombic efficiency of SRFC decreases from 81.8% to 57.0% as the bias increases from 0.1V to 0.3V, suggesting that the higher biases might induce the unfavorable side reactions. The IPCE results reveal that the higher applied potential can promote water oxidation reaction (Fig. S7), which competes with the target reaction of VO2+ oxidation. Photocharge under a low bias of 0.1V, the charge reactions of SRFC will dominate, since the oxidation and reduction of VO2+ are thermodynamically more favorable compared with OER and HER. As a result, a high coulombic efficiency of 81.8% is achieved. While photocharge at a high bias of 0.3V, side reactions will be enhanced and compete with the charge reactions of SRFC due to the improvement of driving force and low concentration of vanadium species. So it is assumed that the low η coulombic under high biases suffers from the side reactions. During the photocharge and discharge process, the saving input electric energy ΔE benefited from incident solar energy could be calculated according to Eq. (5): (5) Δ E = E discharge − E bias = E discharge − U bias C photocharge where E discharge stands for the discharge energy delivered by SRFC, E bias denotes the consumption of electric energy provided by bias, U bias is the applied bias, C photocharge represents the photocharge capacity. On the basis of ΔE, the input electric energy savings percentage of the SRFC could be estimated according to Eq. (6): (6) η savings = Δ E / E discharge × 100 % Table 1 shows that ΔE of 15.5mWh/L and η savings of 67.4% are achieved under a bias of 0.1V, manifesting that SRFC could successfully realize the in-situ storage and utilization of solar energy. With the bias increases to 0.2V, η savings drops obviously to 22.4% (see Table 1), following the same trend with η coulombic . So the further improvement of η savings lies in effective approaches to suppress the side reactions, improve the electrocatalytic activity toward the reduction of VO2+, and enhance the PEC performance in the oxidation of VO2+. Fig. 5 reveals the cycle performance of SRFC photocharged at 0.1V bias. The photocharge capacities of the SRFC keep relatively constant (∼75.0mAh/L) during the cycle life, implying a good cycling stability of the device. 4 Conclusions In summary, a novel SRFC based on photoelectrochemical regeneration of all vanadium redox species has been designed and successfully fabricated for in-situ conversion and storage of solar energy. The SRFC employs TiO2 and MWCNT/AB composite as the photoanode and the counter electrode, respectively, and all vanadium redox couples, VO2 +/VO2+ and VO2+/V3+, as solar energy storage media. By utilizing solar energy, the cell can be photocharged under a bias as low as 0.1V, which is much lower than the discharge voltage (0.5V). Photocharged under the optimized condition, the cell delivers a discharge energy of 23.0mWh/L with 67.4% input electric energy savings. This work may provide much inspiration for the design of cost-effective solar energy conversion and storage devices. Acknowledgments This work was financially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant no. 21573230) and 973 National Basic Research Program of the Ministry of Science and Technology (grant no. 2014CB239400). Supplementary materials Supplementary material associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:10.1016/j.jechem.2017.04.005. coredata.dc:description: Energy storage is pivotal for the continuous utilization of solar energy suffering from the intermittency issue. Herein, we demonstrate a solar rechargeable flow cell (SRFC) based on photoelectrochemical regeneration of vanadium redox species for in-situ solar energy harvest and storage. In this device, TiO2 and MWCNT/acetylene black (MWCNT/AB) composite are served as the photoanode and the counter electrode, respectively, with all vanadium redox couples, VO2 +/VO2+ and VO2+/V3+, as solar energy storage media. Benefitting from solar energy, the cell can be photocharged under a bias as low as 0.1V, which is much lower than the discharge voltage of ∼0.5V. Photocharged under the optimized condition, the cell delivers a discharge energy of 23.0mWh/L with 67.4% input electric energy savings. This prototype work may inspire the rational design for cost-effective solar energy storage devices.

coredata.dc:title: Photoelectrochemical regeneration of all vanadium redox species for construction of a solar rechargeable flow cell
